field.name: Title - type
field.definition: the nature or the genre of the resource being entered

terms.termAndDeftn: a medium of expression consisting of a series of related images, which create the illusion of movement when viewed in rapid succession
primary source materials from the Archives that do not fall under any other title type, such as correspondence, newsletter, or transcript

a self-contained prose composition on a fairly narrow topic or subject, written by one or more authors and published or submitted for publication in a work with a separate title that is a collection or periodical containing works of the same form
a natural object or an object made or modified by one or more persons (replicas excluded)
Bibliography: a list of resources, often with descriptive or critical notes, pertaining to a particular subject, period, author, language, form, place of publication, or some other characteristic

Index: an alphabetically arranged list of headings treated in a work (e.g. names, places, or subjects) and with references to point the user to the location within the resource pertaining to the heading

termAndDeftn.attribution: Online Dictionary for Library and Information Science (OLDIS)

terms.termAndDeftn: Blog: a web page that provides frequent, continuing publication of web links and/or comments on a specific topic (broad or narrow in scope), often in the form of short entries arranged in an orderly fashion, usually chronological.

termAndDeftn.attribution: Online Dictionary for Library and Information Science (OLDIS)

terms.termAndDeftn: Forum/email list: an email discussion forum that allows individuals to subscribe and automatically receive messages posted to the list by other subscribers. Participants may also post their own messages and replies for distribution to the other subscribers to the list.
one of two or more major divisions of a book or other work, each complete in itself but related in theme or structure to the division preceding and/or following it
an evaluative account of a book, usually written by a qualified person for publication in a newspaper, magazine, or journal
Book: a written work or composition that has been published and bound as a single volume
Monograph: a relatively short book or treatise on a single subject, that is complete in one volume, detailed and scholarly but not extensive in scope, and usually written by a specialist in the field
a group of related items that have something in common like a shared topic, intended audience, genre or institution that has sponsored their creation, or shared provenance
a book or numbered set of books containing authoritative summary information about a variety of topics in the form of short essays, usually arranged alphabetically or classified in some manner
a single visual representation
materials designed to respond to input from a human being, usually in the form of commands, data and/or actions

Journal: a periodical devoted to disseminating original research and commentary on current developments in a specific discipline, subdiscipline, or field of study, usually published in quarterly, bimonthly, or monthly issues, and sold by subscription

termAndDeftn.attribution: Online Dictionary for Library and Information Science (OLDIS)

terms.termAndDeftn: Magazine: a popular interest periodical usually containing articles on a variety of topics, written by various authors in a nonscholarly style. Most magazines are heavily illustrated, and contain advertising.

Periodical: a serial publication with its own distinctive title, containing a mix of articles, editorial, reviews, columns, short stories, poems, or other short works written by more than one contributor, generally published at regular stated intervals of less than a year, without prior decision as to when the final issue will appear
a book used as a reference in the operation of a task, computer program, procedure, job or other function
a written and, traditionally, unpublished work or composition
a specification that defines the properties and values of a metadata format

a serial publication consisting of no more than a few pages, devoted to news, announcements, and current information that is of interest primarily to a specialized group of subscribers or members of an association or organization who receive it as part of their membership or affiliation
a visual medium created to publicize a forthcoming event or communicate scholarly or scientific work, with or without illustration
a broadcast, podcast, or formal representation of ideas communicated in person or via the Internet
a record of research findings, research still in progress, or other technical findings, usually bearing a report number and sometimes a grant number assigned by the funding agency
a computer program, application, or model that must be run on a computer server
recorded auditory material that can be heard by the human ear
a written document on a particular subject in which one has done original research that is for a diploma or degree
the written record of words spoken in a speech, interview, broadcast, sound recording or other proceedings

dos.practice: Classify resources by what is created by the author and not what is presented to a user (e.g. OpenSky has just the citation of a paper but still call it an article.).
Classify a resource as a proceedings only when the publisher/sponsor clearly indicates it as such. All other resources should be cataloged as a different type, most likely a presentation or poster.
When using Thesis/dissertation, append the degree name to the title. See examples below.

donts.practice: Do not choose a type if nothing fits. Contact the OpenSky administrator.

examples.practice: Thesis/dissertation - Masters: The saline flow into the Atlantic. M.S. thesis
Thesis/dissertation - PhD: The saline flow into the Atlantic. Ph.D. dissertation

otherPractice.practice: Animation/moving image: use for clips, interviews, lectures, movies
Article: use for reviews general articles, preprints, encyclopedia entries, comments, book forewords, comments on, replys, reply to comments; do not use for book review, use book review instead
Artifact/physical object: use for physical specimens like ice cores, rock samples
Blog/forum/email list: use for message board, chat, weblog
Book/monograph: use for a citation for a whole book
Book review: use for book review only; use article for other reviews
Encyclopedia: use for when referring to the entire encyclopedia
Image: use for photos, maps,
Interactive resource: use for COMET modules, Web Weather for Kids
Manual: use for operations manuals, user guides
Manuscript: use for thesis, dissertation and SOARS papers
Report: use for NCAR technical note
Software: use for computer models like the WRF
Sound: use for voices, music, and natural world and mechanical tones
